children.subject: LSCS is so big that we have to be more specific in how we do reserve seating for the class.
Though like EECS students, we are all required to take it to graduate. It doesn't seem to be equitable to other reserved groups.

I agree with anon above - since all LSCS students need to take EE16B to graduate, I don't see why the reserved seats need to be partitioned so specifically. Furthermore, if LSCS is so large that we need to be more specific in how we reserve seating for the class, it seems that LSCS should be allocated more reserved seats relative to EECS.
There are more CS majors, so they get less spaces allocated to them?This doesn't make sense to me :(
I agree^, it doesn't make sense how the reserved seats are partitioned. Especially since it's required for declared L&S CS students to graduate

I apologize, I should have explained this better. Let me clarify, we reserve seats for all incoming LSCS students that we know are intended CS and we prioritize them off of the waitlist. We also change the number of seats in reserve categories depending on the demand so in reality more seats in these classes go to LSCS students. Since we still have students who don't have to take 16B (those who were admitted before F17), we have to be more specific when it comes to the reserve categories for LSCS because not all LSCS students take the class during their 1-2 years even though it is a lower-division class.  The goal is to have a larger, less restrictive category in the coming years for LSCS students but at this point we still need to make sure that all students of different years are able to enroll and graduate on time. Hope this helps answer the original question. If you have questions or concerns on this, I'd be happy to hear more about it offline. Feel free to email me or stop by my enrollment drop-in hours.
Makes sense thanks!
Why are LSCS students so restricted to EECS16B in terms of reserved seating?

Yes, EECS 106B/206B

106A is only offered in the Fall

Do you mean EECS C106B/206B instead of EECS C106A/206B?

I was thrilled to see that 106A was offering next spring... but it's not actually on the course list.

Very feasible, although you may not always get your first choice of lab. I will email students that are on the waitlist with tips on how to enroll in the class as we get closer to the adjustment period.
anecdotally, do you know how feasible it is to get into eecs16b as a declared l&s junior?
It is on a case-by-case basis
When is the decision made to convert a formerly EE class to an EECS class? To jazz it up so more people want to take it?

16AB are becoming more cs oriented and that’s why they are listed as EECS. As a EE student, honestly, I felt 16AB were like breadth. If you look at EE20/40, the original lower div intro classes, you will find they cover more circuit analysis, transistor operation and signals. 16AB now add more machine learning oriented control, which is obviously at the intersection of CS and EE, so the change of name actually make sense to me.

What is the difference between an EECS class and an EE class? Is EECS the new department name for EE? For example, are EE 105, 130 and, EE 140 now referred to EECS 105, 130, and 140?

Or is this change on a case by case basis and not the entire department's classes are being renamed?

Similar situation, but I'm a declared junior and I'm reluctant to sit on the waitlist while I could make better use of phase 1 by choosing a more desirable breadth.  Would it be safe/reasonable to phase II?

You should Phase 1 it and be strategic in choosing the lab. Choosing popular labs that are likely to fill up will mean that you will need to drop the course and re-add which would add you to the bottom of the WL.
What are good labs to choose?
8am labs or Friday evening labs

Hi, I am an undeclared sophomore in L&S wanting to take EECS16B. Since so little seats are reserved for students like me, would you suggest me not bothering to use Phase I for this class?

Last semester I used Phase I for EECS16A, but stayed on the waitlist until adjustment, so I had to unenroll and reenroll anyway because I had to switch to a lab that was not full, making my choice to Phase I useless.

Do you think I should therefore not bother to use Phase I for EECS16B this time around, or is there still a benefit to using Phase I? Thanks in advance.
Yes you can declare with those 3 classes only, but it would be really hard to get into 16B senior year

not sure if it will be difficult because senior year has the first enrollment time though there may be reserved seats for freshman. can an insturctor confirm this? is it possible to not get in as a senior EECS/CS major into 16B?

Do not wait until your senior year to take 16AB. We reserve large number of seats for you during 1-2 years. This is a lower division class that is meant to be taken before your upper division classes. If you need 16B to graduate, I recommend taking it as soon as possible. It is still possible to get into the class but you will not get priority in the class and will likely not get your first choice in lab which will make your last year more stressful than it needs to be.

I am a sophomore declared CS student, and it seems there is almost no way for me to take this course given there are 10 seats reserved for LSCS sophomore students like me and I am on the later end of enrollment times for sophomores. I know the plan is to open up more spots to LSCS students eventually, but those seats will probably go to the waitlisted LSCS seniors and juniors (and they should, especially if those students need the class to graduate). The recommendation is to take the course as early as possible, yet it seems more likely that I would get in as a senior, since I'd be one of the first ones on the waitlist and enrollment officials would probably prioritize my enrollment if they need to do manual adjustment since it would be more critical for a senior to get in the class by that point. During which year: sophomore, junior, or senior is it most likely that I would get in, if I am a LSCS sophomore now?

During your sophomore year. We try to expand the class to accommodate the waitlist as much as we can (sometimes it is not possible but we do when we can) so the sooner you add it, the better.

I don't check Piazza often and won't be able to respond to every student here to advise on enrollment so please email me if you have concerns on your enrollment or come see me.
Can you still declare cs if you finished 61A, 61B and 70, but not all the lower divs (can we save EE16B for senior year)? Thanks
no, you will need to attend labs.
Is EECS 16B going to have a No Lab option this semester?

We still don't know yet and will update the webcast etc list as soon as we can. 
Heather just posted the list.

Will EE16A offer alternative exams next semester(is it possible to know it now instead of at the beginning of the semester)?

I remember there's a form consisting of information of all EE/CS courses(webcasts, exam conflict, etc.) Where can we access that form? Thank you.
There is no estimated time but I will announce it on Piazza.
When will we know whether an instructor for EE240B has been found?

The only reserve category that we have available in the system for EECS students is a broad category (working on getting new categories created that specifically limit EECS students 1-2 years only but this takes some time to get created by campus). EECS students take 16AB their first year because they come in as declared majors and 16AB is needed as a prereq for a majority of EE upper divs (see HKN's cool EE course map). We rarely see EECS students taking it their junior/senior years.

Hope this addresses the discrepancy. If you have further questions, you are welcome to email me or come see me and I'd be happy to chat with you.

Concerning EE16B, the beginning of this post talks about enrollment priorities being found on classes.berkeley.edu. At the same time, I also am aware of a page on the eecs.berkeley.edu website about getting into EE classes, which gives some conflicting information with classes. For example, classes.berkeley.edu says that there are reserved seats for all EECS students generally, as opposed to eecs.berkeley.edu saying that only first-year and Fall-semester-sophomore EECS students have priority.

So, is the "getting into EE classes" page on eecs.berkeley.edu just out of date--in which case I would only pay attention to classes.berkeley.edu, or am I not reading the information on these websites correctly? Thank you.

There are plans to add another discussion section. We won't be expanding any of the current sections any further. You will have to wait until we add the new discussion. I will email all students that are on the waitlist when the new discussion has been created.

Will there be more discussion sections for eecs 126 or is the current plan to just increase capacity for existing sections? If the class has seat, and I drop myself switch to an open discussion section, would I bypass the lecture waitlist?
I recommend contacting the instructor or CS enrollment manager.
When does the 70% rule usually expire -- specifically asking for 184

Yes, we will expand the class:)
I am working on this right now but I will message everyone on the waitlist with the more information and post on Piazza as soon as everything has been finalized.

Very exciting! Could the seats be allocated to all CS/EECS majors? Waitlisted cs junior for a section with open spots - but no more open seats in class - so if the expansion was just for freshman/sophomore cs students and eecs students it would actually hurt me cause 2nd on waitlist for 6 spots open in a friday lab.
I’m in a bit of a tight situation.  I’m in my senior year for L&S CS and I wasn’t able to claim one of our reserved spots on time. I’m waitlisted at pos 280 hopefully the expansion will apply to me.
Any updates in regards to expanding EE16B?

Are there really no further plans to find an instructor outside the university for EE230B, or offer a W230B? This course is historically offered every Spring and is a very fundamentally core course (to many EE graduate and interested undergraduate students).
Good chance I might get a D (or lower) in EECS 126.  Will it be worth it to retake the class, or just take the hit and move on assuming I don't get an F?

history.content:
Spring 20 EE/EECS enrollment information:

Beginning Spring 2020, EE16AB have changed to EECS16AB. Enrollment Priorities for EECS16A and EECS 16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

  • EE240B: Class removed from schedule until an instructor is found. Plan on taking another class as backup.
    • UPDATE 11/21: course will be offered as W240B. This means that the lecture will be web-based and discussion will take place during lecture time. Class should be available on schedule of classes by end of day.
  • EECS 127/227AT: If there is sufficient interest, we hope to expand to 400. Contact instructor for more info.
    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 400. 
  • EECS 126: There are plans to expand the class. 
    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 261.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16A and EECS16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EECS16A and EECS16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

EE/EECS Enrollment Drop-ins in 205 Cory: 

Week of 2/10-2/14:

Monday  1-4pm

Tuesday  1-2pm, 2-3pm

Wednesday  1-4pm

Thursday 1-4pm

history.subject: EE/EECS, Spring 20 Enrollment Information

history.content:
Spring 20 EE/EECS enrollment information:

Beginning Spring 2020, EE16AB have changed to EECS16AB. Enrollment Priorities for EECS16A and EECS 16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

  • EE240B: Class removed from schedule until an instructor is found. Plan on taking another class as backup.
    • UPDATE 11/21: course will be offered as W240B. This means that the lecture will be web-based and discussion will take place during lecture time. Class should be available on schedule of classes by end of day.
  • EECS 127/227AT: If there is sufficient interest, we hope to expand to 400. Contact instructor for more info.
    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 400. 
  • EECS 126: There are plans to expand the class. 
    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 261.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16A and EECS16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EECS16A and EECS16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

EE/EECS Enrollment Drop-ins in 205 Cory: 

Week of 1/27-1/31:

Monday  1-4pm

Tuesday  3-4pm

Wednesday  1-4pm

Thursday 1-4pm

Friday 1-4pm

    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 400. 
  • EECS 126: There are plans to expand the class. 
    • UPDATE 11/8: course has been expanded to 261.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16A and EECS16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EECS16A and EECS16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

Beginning Spring 2020, EE16AB have changed to EECS16AB. Enrollment Priorities for EECS16A and EECS 16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

  • EECS C106B/206B: All seats temporarily reserved for enrollment by permission only. You can only be added to the waitlist at this time. Class may change time and/or instructor. More information to come.
    • UPDATE 10/31: Class is open, no changes to time.
  • ELENG 123: There are known issues with adding this class on the Schedule Planner. We are currently working through them. You will need to manually add this class with the following class # to enroll: 28402.

  • EE240B: Class removed from schedule until an instructor is found. Plan on taking another class as backup.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

Spring 20 EE/EECS enrollment information:

Beginning Spring 2020, EE16AB have changed to EECS16AB. Enrollment Priorities for EECS16A and EECS 16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

  • EECS C106B/206B: All seats temporarily reserved for enrollment by permission only. You can only be added to the waitlist at this time. Class may change time and/or instructor. More information to come.
  • ELENG 123: There are known issues with adding this class on the Schedule Planner. We are curently working through them. You will need to manually add this class with the following class #: 28402.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16A and EECS16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EECS16A and EECS16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

EE/EECS Enrollment Drop-ins in 205 Cory:

Week of 10/21-10/25

Monday: 1-4pm

Tuesday: 1-2, 3-4pm

Wednesday: 1:30-4pm

Thursday:1-4pm

Friday: 1-4pm
